author: The Editorial Board
title: Britain’s ‘Austerity’ Lesson
text:
The problem with selling government spending as “austerity” is that it encourages voters to think cuts are temporary. That undermines a more important debate about the role and extent of government. Exhibit A is Britain this week.
Chancellor Philip Hammond on Tuesday released his spring statement on the U.K. budget, and the fiscal news is mostly good. The government is slightly raising its predictions of future economic growth. This has boosted tax revenue and reduced—though by no means eliminated—borrowing.
